title: Employer introduces GLA & PHI for higher earners
vignette: Acme Ltd (UK) is introducing a Group Life Assurance (GLA) of 4x salary and a PHI scheme covering 60% of salary after 26 weeks' deferred period. Eligibility is offered to employees earning above £60,000 with 2+ years' service. The broker has proposed a Registered GLA with a master trust and a unit-rated PHI policy. HR is concerned about tax, underwriting, and communications.

questions.stem: For the Registered GLA arrangement, which of the following is typically TRUE with respect to tax?
options: Employer premiums are a taxable benefit in kind for employees
GLA benefits are paid free of income tax when within the Lifetime Allowance
Death benefits are usually written in trust, keeping them outside the estate
Employee contributions are required for Registered GLA to be valid
questions.explanation: Registered GLA is typically written in trust so benefits are usually outside the estate (IHT efficient). Employer premiums are generally not a BiK; Lifetime Allowance limits were historically relevant—but current UK LTA rules have changed. Focus on the trust aspect and current exam wording.

questions.stem: For PHI (income protection), which factor MOST directly affects the unit rate quoted?
options: Whether GLA is registered vs excepted
questions.explanation: PHI pricing is sensitive to benefit design (e.g., 60% of salary) and the deferred period (26 weeks).

questions.stem: Which approach BEST addresses medical underwriting for high earners joining mid-year?
options: Automatic cover level with free cover up to a set multiple; medical evidence above this
No medical underwriting permitted in group schemes
Exclude any condition disclosed in the last 5 years for all members
Require full medicals for everyone regardless of sum assured
questions.explanation: Typical group practice: free cover level (FCL). Above FCL, evidence may be required.

questions.stem: From an employer vs. employee perspective, which communication is MOST appropriate?
options: Employer: emphasise income tax on premiums; Employee: no need to inform beneficiaries
Employer: highlight total reward and risk transfer; Employee: how to nominate beneficiaries and claim steps
Employer: insist on employee contributions; Employee: opt-out is not possible
Employer: avoid discussing exclusions; Employee: assume any illness is covered
questions.explanation: Employers focus on reward/risk transfer; employees need clarity on nominations and claims process.
